I pay homage to the immaculate wheel of the Buddha-sun, the omniscient one,
Whose light of speech destroys the darkness in the minds of humans, gods, and evil destinies.
Those who use the principles of Abhidharma to uproot the ignorance of dharma characteristics,
I bow my head to such a treasury of the words of the omniscient one.
The darkness of false speech by those of inferior wisdom obscures the words of the Sage,
But through the bright lamp, one can illuminate. I bow my head to the one who lights the lamp.

Those who are wise and intelligent are able to fully uphold the words and meanings of the teachings of the Venerable Sage, but due to being constrained by activities, they have not yet attained irreversibility.

Those of inferior wisdom, hearing the dense forest of names and meanings in the Abhidharma, become frightened, yet they always have a mind seeking understanding. Wishing to enable them to joyfully and easily enter the deep whirlpools in the ocean of dharmas and characteristics of the Abhidharma, this treatise is composed.
The teachings of the Well-Gone One have eight categories:
1. Form;
2. Feeling;
3. Perception;
4. Mental formations;
5. Consciousness;
6. Space;
7. Cessation through discernment;
8. Cessation not through discernment. These comprehensively include all meanings.
Form is of two kinds: the primary elements and derivative form.
The primary elements are four: earth, water, fire, and wind.
The elements are so called because they are able to hold their own and common characteristics, or because they are able to hold all derivative forms.

These four great elements, in their order, have solidity, humidity, heat, and motion as their intrinsic natures, and have the functions of supporting, attracting, ripening, and expanding. They are called great elements because they are great and are seeds.

Because of this, space is not included among the great elements, because the meaning of seed is that which can produce its own effect, and it is called great because it is universal in the derivative form.
As for why there are only four of these great elements, it is because there is no need for more, and because there is no capacity for more, just as a bed has four legs.
There are eleven kinds of derivative form:
1. Eye;
2. Ear;
3. Nose;
4. Tongue;
5. Body;
6. Form;
7. Sound;
8. Smell;
9. Taste;
10. Part of tangibility;
11. Non-indicative form.
Because it exists in the great elements, it is called derivative, which means it arises in dependence on the great elements.
Here, eye means the basis of eye consciousness, with the function of seeing forms, having the essence of pure form.
Ear, nose, tongue, and body should be explained in the same way.
Form is of two kinds: manifest and shape.
As the World-Honored One said:
Bad manifest, bad shape.
Here, manifest color has twelve kinds, namely blue, yellow, red, white, smoke, clouds, dust, mist, shadow, light, brightness, and darkness.
Shape color has eight kinds, namely long, short, square, round, high, low, regular, and irregular.
Here, mist means the vapor of earth and water.
Sunlight is called light.
The radiance of the moon, stars, fire, herbs, jewels, lightning, etc. is called brightness.
It arises in the midst of obstructed light.
Other visible colors are called shadow, the opposite of this is called darkness.
Square means quadrangular.
Round means circular.ğŸ”½Shape that is even is called regular.
Shape that is uneven is called irregular.
The other forms are easy to understand, so they are not explained here.
These twenty kinds are all objects cognized by eye consciousness and the mental consciousness it induces.
Sounds are of two kinds: those that are appropriated and those that are not appropriated.
Because of the difference in the great elements that are the cause, those that fall within one's own body are called appropriated, which means they are sounds with awareness;
those that are the opposite of this are called not appropriated.
The former kind is called sounds with appropriated great elements as their cause, such as the sounds of speech, hands, etc.;
the latter kind is called sounds with non-appropriated great elements as their cause, such as the sounds of wind, trees, etc.

These are divided into four kinds according to whether they are called sentient beings or not sentient beings: among the former sounds, the sounds of speech are called sounds of sentient beings, the other sounds are called sounds of non-sentient beings;
among the latter sounds, the sounds of transformed speech are called sounds of sentient beings, the other sounds are called sounds of non-sentient beings.
These are further divided into eight kinds according to whether they are agreeable or disagreeable.
These eight kinds are all objects cognized by the ear consciousness and the mental consciousness induced by it.
There are three kinds of smells:
1. good smells;
2. bad smells;
3. neutral smells.ğŸ”½Smells that can nourish the faculties and the great elements are called good smells;
smells that can harm the faculties and the great elements are called bad smells;
smells that are neither of the above are called neutral smells.
These three kinds are all objects cognized by the nose consciousness and the mental consciousness induced by it.
There are six kinds of tastes, namely sweet, sour, salty, pungent, bitter, and bland.
These six kinds are all objects cognized by the tongue consciousness and the mental consciousness induced by it.
One part of tangibles is of seven kinds, namely smoothness, roughness, heaviness, lightness, cold, hunger, and thirst.
Softness is called smoothness, which is the meaning of being touched by the mind.
Roughness is called roughness.
That which can be weighed is called heavy, and the opposite is called light.
Because of being oppressed by these, the cause of the desire for warmth is called cold, the cause of the desire for food is called hunger, and the cause of the desire for drink is called thirst.
This is all establishing the effect in the name of the cause, and thus speaking like this, just as it is said that the appearance of the Buddhas is joyful, etc.
In a collection of the four great elements, because of the increase of water and fire, there is the quality of smoothness;
because of the increase of earth and wind, there is the quality of roughness;
because of the increase of earth and water, there is the quality of heaviness;
because of the increase of fire and wind, there is the quality of lightness;
because of the increase of water and wind, there is coldness;
because of the increase of wind, there is hunger;
because of the increase of fire, there is thirst.
As for the unmanifest form, it is called manifest because it can manifest the transformation and distinction of various minds and mental factors.
Because it is of the same kind as that but cannot manifest, it is called unmanifest.
This is establishing a prohibitive statement in similarity, just as it is said that the ká¹£atriyas, etc. are not the brahmins, etc.
As for the characteristics of the unmanifest, it is said that it is due to the distinction of the great elements that manifest it.
In the states of sleep, awakening, distraction, non-distraction, and unconsciousness, the continuity of good and bad form cannot be accumulated. This is the characteristic of non-manifest form.
If this did not exist, there would be no establishment of the existence of bhiká¹£us, etc.
As the World-Honored One said, In the matter of meritorious deeds with a basis, merit always increases.
Thus, non-manifest form is generally of three kinds, being included in moral restraint, immoral restraint, and neither.
Moral restraint is of three kinds, namely, prÄtimoká¹£a, dhyÄna, and pure moral restraint, due to the distinction in moral restraint.
PrÄtimoká¹£a moral restraint is of eight kinds:
1. Bhiká¹£u moral restraint;
2. Bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« moral restraint;
3. ÅšrÄmaá¹‡era moral restraint;
4. Åšiká¹£amÄá¹‡Ä moral restraint;
5. ÅšrÄmaá¹‡erÄ« moral restraint;
6. UpÄsaka moral restraint;
7. UpÄsikÄ moral restraint;
Eighth, the precepts of the upavÄsa.
These eight kinds are only bound to the desire realm.
The precepts of meditation are the form that accompanies the samÄdhi of the form realm. They are only bound to the form realm.
The precepts of the uncontaminated are the form that accompanies the uncontaminated samÄdhi. They are only unbound.
The unrestrained are the butchers, hunters, birdcatchers, fishermen, robbers, jailers, dragon tamers, dog cookers, and executioners.
In their bodies, the intimation of non-good continues to turn.

The neither-restrained-nor-unrestrained are those who build monasteries, stÅ«pas, and saá¹ƒghÄrÄmas, and those who pay homage to the caitya, burn incense, scatter flowers, chant praises, and make vows, as well as those who beat and scold, and the various good and bad intimation that continues to turn.
There is also intimation that is only a single moment. Based on the general category, it is said to continue.
The prÄtimoká¹£a restraint is obtained by the vow to receive it. The first seven are maintained as long as life lasts, and the eighth is maintained for one day and night.
Moreover, the first seven are abandoned by four conditions:
first, by abandoning the precepts;
second, by the end of life;
third, by the severing of good roots;
fourth, by the appearance of the two sexes.
The eighth restraint is abandoned by the above four conditions and by the end of the night.
The dhyÄna restraint is obtained by obtaining the wholesome mind of the form realm and is abandoned by abandoning the wholesome mind of the form realm, because it belongs to that mind.
The pure restraint is obtained and abandoned in the same way, because it is obtained and abandoned in accordance with the pure mind.
Nonrestraint is obtained by action and by receiving it. Nonrestraint is abandoned by four conditions:
first, by receiving restraint;
second, by the end of life;
third, by the appearance of the two sexes;
fourth, by the natural obtaining of the wholesome mind of the form realm.
Indeterminate nonmanifest action is obtained by action.
That is, with a sincere and pure mind, or with intense afflictions, one worships and praises stupas, or strikes and beats them.
Or one obtains it through accepting precepts, thinking:
If I do not create a maá¹‡á¸ala for the Buddha, I will never eat first.
Such vows as these.
Or one obtains it through giving up, such as building temples, providing bedding, gardens, and forests for bhiká¹£us, etc.
This non-manifestation is abandoned due to the arising of the mind and the destruction of what is done.

Thus, this non-manifestation and the previously mentioned five faculties such as the eyes are only the objects cognized by the mental consciousness. This is called the initial meaning of the term form.
However, the characteristics of dharmas are roughly of three kinds:ğŸ”½1. Specific and general characteristics;
2. Partial general characteristics;
3. Universal general characteristics.
As for specific and general characteristics, it is called form because it changes and is obstructed, or because it changes and obstructs.
This is said to be the meaning of what can be harmed and destroyed, as stated by the Dharma King:
Bhiká¹£us should know that because of being subject to change and destruction, it is called the form aggregate.
Who can cause change and destruction?
It is said that when touched by the hand, it immediately changes and is destroyed, and so on at length.
Just as one is called a horse because of being able to run fast, and is called an ox because of being able to walk.
The shared characteristic of parts is like impermanence and the nature of suffering, etc.
The universal shared characteristic is like the nature of non-self and the nature of emptiness, etc.
Based on this, one should know the three characteristics of all dharmas.
The meaning of the term feeling refers to the three kinds of sensation:
1. pleasant,
2. painful,
3. neither pleasant nor painful, which is the meaning of experiencing the three kinds of contact.
It arises from contact that is desirable, undesirable, or neither.
It arises from the distinction of the physical and mental states, and its characteristics are joy, sorrow, and indifference towards objects. It is called feeling because it is the cause of craving.
As the World-Honored One said:
Contact is the condition for feeling, and feeling is the condition for craving.
Furthermore, according to the distinction of consciousness, there are six kinds, namely, feeling born from eye contact, up to feeling born from mind contact.
Feeling born with the five consciousnesses is called bodily feeling, and that born with mental consciousness is called mental feeling.

translated: The five kinds are established according to the distinction of faculties, namely, the faculty of pleasure, the faculty of pain, the faculty of joy, the faculty of depression, and the faculty of equanimity.
Bodily pleasant feeling and mental pleasant feeling in the third trance state are called the faculty of pleasure.
Pleasant means the meaning of benefit.
Bodily unpleasant feeling is called the faculty of pain.
Unpleasant means the meaning of harm.
Except for the third trance state, other mental pleasant feelings are called the faculty of joy.
Mental unpleasant feeling is called the faculty of depression.
Bodily and mental feelings that are neither pleasant nor unpleasant are called the faculty of equanimity.
This is extensively distinguished like the faculties and other topics.
As for the meaning of the term conception, it means being able to provisionally combine the characteristics, names, and meanings.

It is the mental factor that, in regard to the characteristics and names of colors such as blue and yellow, long and short, sounds such as conch and drum, smells such as musk and sandalwood, tastes such as salty and bitter, tactile objects such as hard and soft, and phenomena such as male and female, combines them and understands them, and is the cause of applied thought and sustained thought. Therefore, it is called conceptualization.
This [conceptualization] is distinguished according to consciousness and has six aspects, like feeling.
There are three distinctions of small, large, and immeasurable. That which takes few objects is called small conceptualization;
that which takes sublime and equal great dharmas as objects is called large conceptualization;
that which follows the sphere of infinite space, etc. is called immeasurable conceptualization.
Or these three names are established according to the three realms.
There are two kinds of volitional activity, namely associated volitional activity and non-associated volitional activity.

Associated factors are volition, contact, desire, attention, resolve, memory, concentration, discernment, applied thought, sustained thought, faith, diligence, conscience, shame, heedfulness, tranquility, non-violence, equanimity, disgust, lack of faith, laziness, negligence, wholesome roots, unwholesome roots, indeterminate roots, bonds, fetters, latent afflictions, secondary afflictions, entanglements, outflows, floods, bonds, bodily ties, hindrances, and various mental factors such as knowledge and patience. These are called associated because they are equal in five aspects with the mind that supports them, their objects, their mode of activity, time, and substance.

Those that are contrary to this are called non-associated, namely acquisition, non-acquisition, the attainment of non-perception, the attainment of cessation, the state of non-perception, the faculty of life, the similarity of species, birth, abiding, aging, impermanence, the collection of names, the collection of phrases, and the collection of letters, etc.
Such associated and nonassociated compositional factors are collectively called the aggregate of compositional factors.
Thus the Great Sage said:
The aggregate of compositional factors is like a bunch of bananas.
Volition is that which makes the mind active, which is mental action, and also means that which moves the mind.
This is of three kinds, good, bad, and indeterminate.

Contact is that which is born from the union of faculty, object, and consciousness, which causes the mind to contact the object, and whose characteristic is that of nourishing the mental activities. It is of three kinds, corresponding to pleasant, unpleasant, and neutral feelings.
Desire is that which aspires to create an activity and conforms to vigor, meaning that one thinks, I will do such and such an activity.

Attention is that which causes the mind to be alert, which means that it attracts the mind to an object. It also means that one remembers what one has experienced. It is of three kinds, namely, that of one still learning, that of one beyond learning, and that of neither one still learning nor one beyond learning.
The attention of learners is called learning, that of arhats is called post-learning, and that of all those who are neither learners nor post-learners is called neither-learning-nor-post-learning.
Resolution is the ability to affirm a cognitive object, which is the meaning of causing the mind to be without timidity with regard to the cognitive object.
Recollection is the ability to cause the mind to clearly remember a cognitive object, which is the meaning of non-forgetting.
That which is done, is being done, and will be done is the meaning of activity.

SamÄdhi is the ability to cause the mind to concentrate on a single cognitive object, which is the meaning of controlling the mind, which is like a monkey, to move only with regard to a single cognitive object.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say: Just as a snake moves in a straight line when in a tube, so the mind moves in a straight line when in samÄdhi.
Wisdom is the ability to discriminate dharmas, which is the meaning of the causes and conditions of grasping, association, and accomplishment;
the eight kinds of dharmas of specific characteristics and common characteristics, according to what is appropriate, are observed as the meaning.
Seeking is the characteristic of causing the mind to be coarse with regard to an object, and is also called discrimination and reflection.
Bound by the wind of conceptualization, it turns coarse and agitated. This dharma is the cause for the arising of the five consciousnesses.

Scrutiny is the characteristic of causing the mind to be subtle with regard to an object. This dharma is the cause for the mind to follow along with the arising of consciousness with regard to an object.

Faith is the characteristic of causing the mind to be clear and pure with regard to an object. It is called faith because it is the acquiescence and acceptance of the connection between the three jewels and cause and effect, the nature of existence, etc.
It is able to eliminate the turbid defilements of the mind, just as when a clear water jewel is placed in a pond, it causes the turbid and defiled water to all become clear and pure.
In the same way, when the jewel of faith is in the pond of the mind, the turbid defilements of the mind are all immediately eliminated.

Faith in the Buddha's realization of enlightenment, faith in the Dharma being well-taught, faith in the Saá¹…gha's possession of wonderful practices, and also faith in the nature of dependent origination that is confused by all non-Buddhists, are the activities of faith.

VIGOR is by nature the courage to generate and extinguish good and bad dharmas, that is, the meaning of being able to incite the mind to quickly escape from the mud of transmigration.ğŸ”½CONSCIENCE is by nature the independence of mind that is born of the superior power of the pure dharmas that follow the correct principles of nature and that opposes the defiled mind stream of craving, etc. It is the power of respect for the good dharmas and those who possess them.
EMOLUMENT is by nature the power of respect for the good dharmas and those who possess them. It is the power of respect for the good dharmas and those who possess them.
NON-NEGLECT is by nature the cultivation of good dharmas, opposing neglect, and guarding the nature of the mind.
LIGHTNESS is by nature the fitness of mind, opposing torpor and following the good dharmas.
HARMLESSNESS is by nature the goodness of the firmness of mind, because by its power one does not injure others and it opposes the harming of others.

Equanimity of mind is called equanimity because it turns away from that which is not reasonable and turns toward that which is reasonable. As a consequence of its power, the mind remains in equanimity toward that which is reasonable and that which is not, neither turning toward nor away from them, just as a scale suspended by a rope remains in equilibrium when there is no additional weight on either side.

Delight is the delight and approval of the mind that is directed toward the category of cessation, having seen its virtues. It is the cause that makes the mind delight in and enjoy nirvÄá¹‡a. The attention associated with it is called the attention of delight.

Disgust is the disgust and aversion of the mind that is directed toward the category of transmigration, having seen its faults. It is the cause that makes the mind abhor saá¹ƒsÄra and conform to the abandonment of passion.
Lack of faith is the lack of clarity of the mind. It is the opposite of faith, as explained above.
Laziness is the lack of courage and strength of the mind. It is the opposite of vigor, as explained above.
Negligence is the failure to cultivate good dharmas. It is the opposite of vigilance, as explained above. It is the inability to guard the mind.
The three, unbelief, etc., are not established as latent tendencies or entanglements and secondary afflictions because their faults are slight and they are easily eliminated.
There are three kinds of roots of goodness:
First, non-greed, which is the dharma that opposes greed;
second, non-hatred, which is the dharma that opposes hatred;
third, non-delusion, which is the dharma that opposes delusion, and which has the nature of wisdom as explained above.
These three dharmas are the intrinsic nature of goodness, and they can also serve as roots to produce other good dharmas, therefore they are called roots of goodness.

The meaning of peace and security is the meaning of goodness, because it can attract desirable existence and the seeds of liberation, or the meaning of skillfully learning and becoming adept is the meaning of goodness, because it can accomplish wonderful forms, like a painter who creates wonderful forms is called good in the world.
There are three kinds of roots of non-good, which are the greed, hatred, and delusion that were previously to be eliminated.

Greed is the five classes of greed in the desire realm, anger is the five classes of anger, and delusion is the thirty-four ignorances in the desire realm, excluding the ignorance associated with the view of self and the view grasping extremes.
These three dharmas are by nature unwholesome, and they can also serve as roots producing other unwholesome dharmas, and are therefore called roots of unwholesome dharmas.

The meaning of unwholesome is the meaning of not being at ease, because it can attract the sprouts of non-love, or the meaning of unwholesomeness is the meaning of not yet learning skillful means, because it can accomplish an evil form, like a painter's creation that is not wonderful, the world calls it unwholesome.
There are four kinds of roots of indeterminate dharmas, namely craving, views, pride, and ignorance.
Craving is the five classes of greed in the form and formless realms.
Views are the twelve views in the form and formless realms, as well as the view of self and the view grasping extremes in the desire realm.
Pride is the five classes of pride in the form and formless realms.
Ignorance refers to all ignorance in the form and formless realms, as well as ignorance associated with the view of self and extreme views in the desire realm.
These four indeterminate roots are accepted as being due to the differences in the three types of practitioners who cultivate meditative concentration:

1. those who are attached to love in meditative concentration, 2. those who are attached to views in meditative concentration, and 3. those who are attached to pride in meditative concentration. These three all arise due to the power of ignorance.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas establish that there are only three types of indeterminate roots, namely the three of indeterminate craving, ignorance, and discernment.
Doubt does not firmly abide, and chronic pride is not the nature of a root. Because it does not record good or bad meanings, it is called indeterminate.
Moreover, it cannot record the fruits of love and non-love, so it is called indeterminate.

Because it cannot attract the result of retribution, it is of the indeterminate nature. It can also give rise to other indeterminate defiled dharmas or various indeterminate dharmas, so it is called an indeterminate root.
There are nine kinds of bonds, namely, the bonds of craving, anger, pride, ignorance, views, grasping, doubt, jealousy, and stinginess.
The bond of craving refers to the craving of the three realms. Its characteristic is that of attachment, like melted glue or lacquer, and is therefore called craving.
Craving itself is a bond, and is therefore called the bond of craving.
The bond of anger refers to the five kinds of anger. It is the characteristic of harming and causing suffering to sentient beings, like a bitter seed, and is therefore called anger.
Anger itself is a bond, and is therefore called the bond of anger.

The bond of pride refers to the pride of the three realms. Its characteristic is that of the mind being arrogant and conceited due to the distinctions in one's own and others' virtues, like an arrogant person who looks down on others.
This is further divided into seven kinds:
1. Pride;
2. Exaggerated pride;
3. Pride of superiority;
4. Pride of self;
5. Pride of thinking oneself superior;
6. Pride of inferiority;
Seventh, wrong pride.

It means that due to family lineage, wealth, status, appearance, strength, upholding precepts, extensive learning, craftsmanship, etc., if one considers oneself superior to an inferior, or equal to an equal, this causes the mind to be arrogant and is called pride.ğŸ”½If one considers oneself superior to an equal, or equal to a superior, this causes the mind to be arrogant and is called excessive pride.
If one considers oneself superior to a superior, this causes the mind to be arrogant and is called pride-excessive pride.
If one grasps at the five appropriated aggregates as I and mine, this causes the mind to be arrogant and is called pride of self.
If one considers oneself to have attained the excellent qualities of a stream-enterer, etc., which one has not yet attained, this causes the mind to be arrogant and is called overweening pride.
If one considers oneself slightly inferior to those superior in family lineage, etc., this causes the mind to be arrogant and is called debased pride.
If one considers oneself to have virtues when one actually lacks them, this causes the mind to be arrogant and is called wrong pride.
These seven types of pride are collectively called the fetter of pride.

The fetter of ignorance is the nescience of the three realms. Its characteristic is that of non-understanding, because it is contrary to and harmful to understanding, and for that reason it is called ignorance.
This word â€œfetterâ€ has the meaning of an antidote, just as the words â€œnon-friendâ€ and â€œunrealâ€ have the meaning of an enemy and a lie, respectively.
Ignorance is itself a fetter, and therefore it is called the fetter of ignorance.
The fetter of views is the three views, namely, the view of the existence of a person, the view of grasping extremes, and false views.

In the five grasped aggregates there is no self or possession of a self, but one grasps the characteristics of a real self and possession of a self. This defiled discernment is called the view of the existence of a person.
The word â€œpersonâ€ means a collection. Because there is existence in the person, it is called the existence of a person.
One generates views about the five grasped aggregates, and this is called the view of the existence of a person.

The five grasped aggregates are neither annihilated nor eternal, but one grasps the two characteristics of annihilation and eternity in them. This defiled discernment is called the view of grasping extremes, because one grasps two extremes.
If one definitely grasps that there is no karma, no karmic fruits, no liberation, and no path to attain liberation, denying real entities, this defiled discernment is called wrong view.
These three views are called the fetter of views.
The fetter of grasping refers to the two kinds of grasping, namely the grasping of views and the grasping of precepts and vows.
That is, the first three views and the five aggregates of clinging are actually not supreme but are grasped as supreme. This defiled discernment is called the grasping of views.
Grasping means seeking and firmly grasping.

Precepts refer to the avoidance of the evil of breaking precepts and vows. Vows refer to the practice of crow, chicken, deer, and dog [ascetic practices], going naked, pulling out hair, fasting and sleeping on ashes, or in the case of false beliefs in the creation of merit and the elimination of offenses, repeatedly bathing in various rivers and ponds, or sustaining oneself by eating roots, fruits, grass, vegetables, and herbs, or applying ashes and pulling out hair, all of which are called vows.
These two are both not the path to purification, yet one falsely grasps them as the path to purification. This defiled discernment is called the grasping of precepts and vows.

The brahmins who are well-versed in the scriptures, for the most part, adhere to this teaching as the pure path, yet they are unable to attain ultimate purity. These two attachments are called the fetters of attachment.

The fetter of doubt means being undecided about the four noble truths, like seeing a scarecrow at a crossroads and hesitating without deciding. In the same way, one is undecided about suffering, wondering if it is so or not, and so on.
Doubt itself is a fetter, so it is called the fetter of doubt.

The fetter of jealousy means being unable to bear the excellence of others, that is, being envious of others' respect, offerings, wealth, status, learning, and other superior qualities. This is the meaning of being unable to bear.
Jealousy itself is a fetter, so it is called the fetter of jealousy.
The fetter of stinginess means being miserly with one's own teachings and wealth, thinking, Let my possessions not reach others.
Stinginess itself is a fetter, so it is called the fetter of stinginess.
The meaning of fetter is the meaning of bondage, as the World-Honored One said:
It is not that the eyes are bound by form, nor that form is bound by the eyes. Here, desire and greed are called bonds.
It is not that a black ox is bound by a white ox, nor that a white ox is bound by a black ox, and so on at length.
The bonds mentioned earlier are also the fetters, because the meaning of bonds is the same as the meaning of fetters.
However, the sutras also speak of three fetters:ğŸ”½First, the fetter of greed, which refers to all greed, as explained in the characteristics of the fetter of craving.
Second, the fetter of hatred, which refers to all hatred, as explained in the characteristics of the fetter of ill-will.
Third, the fetter of delusion, which refers to all delusion, as explained in the characteristics of the fetter of ignorance.
There are seven kinds of latent tendencies:
First, the latent tendency of desire and greed;
Second, the latent tendency of hatred;ğŸ”½Third, the latent tendency of craving for existence;
Fourth, the latent tendency of pride;
Fifth, the latent tendency of ignorance;
Sixth, the latent tendency of views;
Seventh, the latent tendency of doubt.
The distinct characteristics of these seven are explained in the section on fetters.

However, you should distinguish these seven kinds of latent afflictions according to the realms, aspects, and categories. That is, because one is attached to desires, it is called attachment to desires.
This attachment is also a latent tendency, so it is called the latent tendency of attachment to desires.
This is only in the desire realm, and the five categories are the five, namely, those eliminated by seeing the truth of suffering, up to those eliminated by cultivation.
The latent tendency of anger is also only in the desire realm, and the five categories are the five.
The latent tendency of attachment to existence is only in the form and formless realms, each with five categories, totaling ten. Because it occurs internally.
In order to prevent the idea that the liberations of the meditative absorptions and formless realms are liberation, it is said that the attachment of the two realms is called attachment to existence.
The latent tendency of pride is common to the three realms, each with five categories, totaling fifteen.
The latent tendency of ignorance is also the same.

The latent afflictions of views are of three realms, each with twelve, making thirty-six. In the desire realm, those eliminated by seeing suffering are complete with five views. Those eliminated by seeing the origin and cessation are only the two of wrong views and views of holding as paramount. Those eliminated by seeing the path are only the three of wrong views, views of holding as paramount, and views of holding precepts and practices as paramount, totaling twelve. The upper two realms are also thus, making thirty-six.
The latent afflictions of doubt are of three realms, each with four categories, making twelve. They are eliminated by seeing suffering, the origin, cessation, and the path.
Here, the latent afflictions of desire and anger only have the distinction of categories, not the distinction of realms and aspects.
The latent afflictions of desire for existence, doubt, pride, and ignorance have the distinction of realms and categories, not the distinction of aspects.
The latent afflictions of views have the distinction of realms, aspects, and categories.
The distinction of aspects refers to the aspects of self and what belongs to self. Those that arise with these aspects are called the view of the aggregates as the self.

The mode of activity of the view of annihilation is called extreme view, the mode of activity of the view of nonexistence is called false view, the mode of activity of the view of superiority is called clinging to views, and the mode of activity of the view of purity is called clinging to precepts and vows.
The meaning of subtlety is the meaning of latent tendency, because when they are manifested, they are difficult to perceive.

Or the meaning of following and binding is the meaning of latent tendency, that is, following the body and mind and turning with them, because they follow like a shadow follows form and like water follows movement.
Or the meaning of following is the meaning of latent tendency, because it is like oil in hemp and grease in dough.

Or the meaning of following increase is the meaning of latent tendency, that is, because they follow and increase in the five appropriated aggregates by means of the aspect of the object and association.
As for following increase, it means that they increase and grow by following the object and the aspect of association.
These seven kinds of latent tendencies, due to the distinctions of realm, mode of activity, and category, become ninety-eight latent tendencies.

That is, in the realm of desire, there are ten proclivities that are eliminated by insight into the truths of suffering, namely, satkÄya view, extreme view, false view, clinging to views, clinging to morality and asceticism, ignorance, craving, hatred, pride, and doubt.

There are seven proclivities that are eliminated by insight into the truth of the origin of suffering, namely, the above ten with the exception of satkÄya view, extreme view, and clinging to morality and asceticism.
There are also seven proclivities that are eliminated by insight into the truth of cessation.
There are eight proclivities that are eliminated by insight into the truth of the path, namely, the above seven plus clinging to morality and asceticism.
There are four proclivities that are eliminated by cultivation, namely, craving, hatred, pride, and ignorance.
Thus there are thirty-six proclivities in the realm of desire.

There are thirty-one proclivities in the realm of form, namely, the above thirty-six with the exception of the five classes of hatred. The formless realm is also like this. Therefore there are ninety-eight proclivities.
Among them, eighty-eight are eliminated by insight, and ten are eliminated by cultivation.

Thirty-three are universal, namely, the views, doubts, and independent ignorance associated with them that are eliminated by seeing suffering and its cause in each of the three realms. The rest are not universal.
Eighteen are with impure objects, namely, the wrong views, doubts, and independent ignorance associated with them that are eliminated by seeing cessation and the path in each of the three realms.
These eighteen are called with impure objects because they take cessation and the path as objects. The rest are with impure objects.
Among these, those with impure objects increase by taking objects and being associated.
Those with pure objects only increase by being associated with their own aggregates.
Nine are with unconditioned objects, namely, the wrong views, doubts, and independent ignorance associated with them that are eliminated by seeing cessation in each of the three realms.
They are called with unconditioned objects because they take the truth of cessation as their object. The rest are with conditioned objects.
As for the order in which the ten kinds of latent afflictions arise, first, due to ignorance, one does not understand the truths, namely, suffering, and does not desire up to the path.

Because of this lack of understanding, doubt is next produced, because one hears both correct and incorrect teachings and is uncertain, wondering whether there is suffering or not, and so on, up to wondering whether there is the path or not.
From this doubt, wrong views are produced, because one generates wrong decisions through evil friends and wrong hearing and thinking, saying that there is no giving, no love, no sacrifice, and so on.

From this wrong view, the view of the existence of a self is produced, because when one denies the principle of suffering in the aggregates that are taken up, one then grasps the existence of a self or something belonging to a self.

From the view of the existence of a self, the view of grasping extremes is produced, because one grasps the extremes of eternalism and annihilationism with regard to the self.ğŸ”½From the view of grasping extremes, the clinging to views is produced, because one grasps these extremes as being able to purify.
From the clinging to views, the clinging to dharmas is produced, because one grasps what is able to purify as being the most excellent.
From this clinging to dharmas, craving is produced, because one deeply loves one's own views.
After craving, conceit is produced, because after one is deeply attached to oneâ€™s own views, one gives rise to conceit and looks down on others.
After conceit, anger is produced, because one cannot tolerate the views of others and one necessarily hates them. Or, one hates the views of others because one is attached to oneâ€™s own views.
This is the order of the ten proclivities.
The various passions arise from three causes:
1) the non-eradication of the proclivities,
2) incorrect mental attention,
3) the presence of an object.
The passions appear through the power of these three causes, cause, activity, and object. This is said of the case where all three are present.
There are also cases where the passions appear through the power of the object alone. They are called passions because they disturb and afflict body and mind.ğŸ”½They are also called proclivities.
The secondary passions are also called passions.
There are also secondary passions, which are all the defiled mental activities included in the aggregate of formations, because they are categorized as the same aggregates as the passions.
What are they?
They are deceit, pride, harmfulness, anger, resentment, guile, and so on, which are innumerable, as explained in the holy teachings.
DECEIT is deceiving others.

PRIDE is, having become attached to oneâ€™s own good qualities of physical appearance, strength, family, morality, learning, eloquence, etc., to make the mind arrogant and haughty and to be unconcerned with others.
HARMFULNESS is the ability to oppress others, because of which one can carry out such things as beating and scolding.
ANGER is the firm grasping of all sinful things, because of which one does not accept good advice.
RESENTMENT is the repeated investigation of the object of anger and the inability to let go of the resentment and forget it.
GUILE is the crookedness of the mind.
These six are born from the passions.
They are called the defilements of the passions.
Among these six kinds of defilement-muddiness, the two of deceit and arrogance are the outflow of craving, because they are of the same species as craving.
The two of harm and resentment are the outflow of hatred, because they are of the same species as hatred.
The muddiness of vexation is the outflow of the view of grasping at views as paramount, because one who grasps at one's own views as superior vexatiously disturbs oneself and others.
The muddiness of flattery is the outflow of the various views, because flattery is crooked and there are many views.
As it is said, Flattery is the various evil views. These muddinesses, entanglements, and other defiled mental activities are all included in the aggregate of mental activities.
Because all mental activities arise from the defilements, they are all called secondary defilements.
There are ten kinds of entanglements, namely torpor, sleep, restlessness, worry, envy, stinginess, lack of conscience, lack of shame, anger, and concealment.

The characteristics of mental factors are subtle. Each continuum is difficult to distinguish, let alone all existing simultaneously in one moment.
The one with subtle and secret wisdom, relying on the Buddha's teachings, observes the differences in effects and knows their different natures. He proclaims them to learners without error.

Those with inferior wisdom have not personally attended and served teachers who explain the Buddha's words without error. Therefore, they are confused and deny the mental factors, either saying there are only three or that they do not exist at all.
There are three kinds of defilements, namely the defilement of desire, the defilement of existence, and the defilement of ignorance.
The afflictions of the desire realm and the entanglements, excluding ignorance, are called the leakage of desire.
There are forty-one substances, namely the thirty-one latent afflictions and the ten entanglements.
The afflictions of the form and formless realms and the entanglements, excluding ignorance, are called the leakage of existence.

There are fifty-four substances, namely the twenty-six latent afflictions of each of the two upper realms, plus torpor and restlessness, because they are both indeterminate, because they operate internally, and because they rely on the stages of concentration. The two realms are combined and one leakage of existence is established.
Ignorance of the three realms is called the leakage of ignorance, with fifteen substances. Because ignorance is the basis of all existence, it is separately established as a leakage, etc.
